title: The Practical Guide to Becoming Actually Smarter

meaningful_segments.text: So you want to become smart. In most of the world, you're told that it takes 12 years of school, plus four years of college, plus six years of graduate school to become smart.
Becoming smart is actually very easy. Even if you think your genetics make you dumb, if you compare yourself to every other animal, you're actually pretty overpowered.

When people like you and me say we want to get smarter, it means a bunch of things. We want to learn useful skills. Ideally, skills that make money. We want to be good at solving problems. We want to get better grades and learn difficult subjects.

The problem is, most advice on the internet is so vague. Eat blueberries, drink black coffee, exercise, sleep more. These things sound good, but at some point you have to, you know, actually learn stuff.
So what can you actually do to get smarter? The main thing you need to do is read. Fiction is good for learning to read faster and it gives you a better vocabulary.
But most people go straight for nonfiction, which indeed is the key to being able to casually drop interesting knowledge in conversations. The key is to not be obnoxious about it.

You can be smart while also being humble and also sounding like you touch grass. The key is to teach people what you know without making them sound dumb. This way, people will actually learn from you, which will make them see you as smart and respectable.

You'll also find that not only can you pick out interesting tidbits to use in conversations, but you can also learn many useful skills. One, unless you practice the skill, your brain will think it's useless and forget it. Two, you only have to know 20% of the knowledge to master 80% of the skill.

This is called the learning curve. As you can see, just by practicing a little bit, you can make a lot of progress in the beginning, but you have to practice. Books only make you smart if you give your brain a reason to remember the stuff in the book.

Imagine you're reading a book about cars, and you see this diagram of how to jumpstart a dead car. You can still practice it by just imagining. By imagining the whole process from start to finish, you just convinced your brain that you used all that information, and now you'll remember it.

This is how you get smart. Use everything you learn, and if you can't, imagine yourself in the moment where it'll be useful. This is basically how the entire school system works. You learn a piece of information, and your teacher creates an imaginary situation where that information is useful. That is, a test.

Some people think repetition or mind mapping will help them. But in reality, doing practice questions will give you the most results, because they simulate the actual situation in which you'll need to use what you learned.

Learning information and making it seem useful to your brain is all you need to get smart. And this is why textbooks are the S-tier format for becoming smart as fast as possible. There's no fluff, no hand holding, no distractions, just pure information, and a bunch of practice questions.
